6. Sequence stratigraphy framework 314
In the last 30 years, many authors have attempted to use the sequence 315
stratigraphic models of passive-margin basin to understand the evolution and the 316
sedimentary filling in different types of basins, despite fundamental differences in 317
terms of the mechanisms controlling the tectono-stratigraphy of these basins. 318
Depositional sequences in passive margin begin with a forced regression (base-319
level fall) that causes subaerial exposure, and erosion, with the establishment of 320
‘lowstand fans’ in the deeper part of the basin. Then, a base-level rise characterizes 321
a retrogradational trend with a positive accommodation and a low sediment supply, 322
inducing the progressive establishment of deeper-water environments, such as 323
marine carbonates and black shales. The accommodation space created by rising 324
sea level is then progressively filled by sediments from the continental wedge, in a 325
relatively stable interplay between accommodation and sediment supply (aggradation 326
or normal progradation). The succession of these depositional trends, represented by 327
variations between rates of accommodation (positive and negative) and sediment 328
supply (low or high), allows sub-divisions of the depositional sequence into lowstand 329
(negative accommodation, high sediment supply), transgressive (positive 330
accommodation, low sediment supply) and highstand (balance between 331
accommodation and sediment supply) systems tract. 332
In contrast with passive-margin basins where cyclic sea level fluctuations control 333
the sedimentary architecture, accommodation in rift basins is dominantly created, or 334
lost, as a result of tectonic activity (mechanical subsidence). Martins-Neto & 335
Catuneanu (2009, in press) proposed a model to provide a better understanding of 336
the evolution and the stratigraphic record in rift basins. During syn-rift continental 337
sedimentation (such as the Barra de Itiúba Formation), subsidence with a short stage 338
14
of rapid creation of accommodation is mainly linked to pulses of extension and border 339
normal-fault reactivation, although climatic controls and lake base-level fluctuations 340
may operate at high frequency on the stratigraphic cyclicity. According to this model, 341
a complete depositional sequence in rift basins begins with a short retrogradational 342
cycle (transgressive succession, underfilled phase) in response to the tectonic pulse 343
of extensional subsidence, followed by a longer progradational trend during the 344
tectonic quiescence corresponding to the “filled phase”, when sediment supply 345
consumes the available accommodation space created during the extensional 346
subsidence. Stratigraphically, it results in a thin fining-upward succession (shallow-347
water), followed by a thicker coarsening-upward succession during the filled phase. 348
In the later stages, the available accommodation space can be fully filled by coastal 349
deltaic deposits, and erosive distributary channels associated with proximal delta 350
plain deposits (crevasse splay, interdistributary bay, paleosols) forming the overfilled 351
phase. This erosive transition reflects the shift from “filled” to “overfilled” phase. 352
In our sequences interpreted and adapted (Fig. 4) according to this model, the 353
identification of the "filling surface” (FS), usually marked by the appearance of the 354
first thick distributary channels, was chosen as the transition marker between "filling 355
phase" and the last “overfilled phase”, and usually represents the beginning of the 356
“overfilled systems tract” (OST) which conclude the sequence (SB). It was also 357
chosen to call the "filled systems tract" (FST), which starts already from the maximum 358
flood surface (SIM), generally as the beginning of delta progradation in prodelta-359
lacustrine environment, due to the difficulty of locating exactly where accommodation 360
is in balance with sediment supply (sensu Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in 361
press). 362
Depending of the sequence scale order (2 th
/3 th
order), a new tectonic pulse marks 363
the initiation of a new rift sequence by the creation of a consequent “instantaneous” 364
15
accommodation space (Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press), leading to a 365
change from an “overfilled” to a new “underfilled” phase. 366
Include Figure. 4 367
The sequence stratigraphic model proposed by Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009, 368
in press) is the one that best applies to understanding the stratigraphy record of the 369
syn-rift Barra de Itiúba Formation. In well sections (Fig. 5, 6), seven complete 3 th
-370
order depositional sequences can be identified, mostly composed of unferfilled, filled, 371
and overfilled systems tracts (sensu Martins-Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press), 372
recognized and correlated across the study area (Fig. 7). Using ostracod biozones 373
and the recognition of a regional erosive surface formed by coarse-grained 374
sandstones onto fine-grained lacustrine deposits (Borba, 2011), the identification of 375
the “Pre-Aratu Unconformity” (PAU) in well A (1958,70m) and well B (1624, 40m) 376
mark the lithostratigraphic transition between the underlying Feliz Deserto Formation 377
(Neocomian, Rio da Serra local stage) and the Barra de Itiúba Formation (Barremian, 378
Aratu to Buracica local stages), related to the second major tectonic pulse (2 th
order) 379
in the Sergipe-Alagoas rift succession. 380

6.1. Sequence 1 383
This sequence, 10 to 34 m thick, represents the onset of the second pulse of 384
tectonic. In the Sergipe sub-basin (well A), the sequence is bounded at the base by a 385
sharp erosional unconformity that separates fine-grained lacustrine deposits of the 386
Feliz Deserto Formation (PAU) from coarse-grained sandstones deposited by 387
distributary channels, the first deposits of the Barra de Itiúba Formation. The 388
sequence in only represented by the progradational trends (FST, OST) and it shows 389
16
a thin coarsening-upward succession composed of interbedded crevasse splay and 390
interdistributary bay deposits. In the Alagoas sub-basin (well B), the underfilled 391
systems tract was preserved, with the deposition of thin lacustrine deposits, rapidly 392
covered by prograding distal delta front deposits which represent the beginning of the 393
filled phase. The overfilled phase begins with the deposition of erosive thick 394
conglomerates of distributary channel (FS, 1615.20 m), probably from proximal 395
deltaic plain, followed and intercalated with crevasse splay in middle part of the 396
succession. 397
6.2. Sequence 2 398
Sequence 2, 55 m to 108 m thick, begins with a new retrogradational trend (UST) 399
in which deltaic to lacustrine deposits overlie the flooding surface (SB 1), in response 400
to the rapid subsidence created by a new tectonic pulse. In the Alagoas sub-basin, 401
lacustrine deposits directly overlie the flooding surface, suggesting fast and high 402
creation of accommodation space. The filled systems tract forms the bulk of the 403
sequence, with a thick, well-defined progradational coarsening-upward succession 404
(delta progradation) during the filled phase. This coarsening-upward succession is 405
very well represented in the Sergipe sub-basin (well A), with the vertical evolution 406
from distal (lacustrine, prodelta) deposits to distal delta front deposits (fluidized, fine-407
grained sandstones), overlain by medium to fine-grained trough-cross stratified 408
sandstones (proximal delta front). The overfilled phase completes the sequence, with 409
the deposition of erosive distributary channel associated with crevasse splay 410
deposits, onto delta front deposits. 411
6.3. Sequence 3 412
This sequence, 27 m to 123 m thick, leads off with a short underfilled systems 413
tract represented by the deposition of organic-rich lacustrine mudstones covering the 414
17
flooding surface (SB 2). During the filled phase, the succession passes upward to 415
greenish bioturbated prodelta mudstones and delta front sandstones. 416
In the Sergipe portion, the filled phase, relatively thinner, is covered by thick 417
erosive distributary channel deposits interlayed with crevasse splay and 418
interdistributary bay deposits formed during a relatively early overfilled phase. In the 419
Alagoas portion (well B), the succession is thicker and shows a slight coarsening-420
upward succession, overlain by thin erosive distributary channel deposits interlayered 421
with delta and prodelta deposits. 422
Thus, it appears that the magnitude of tectonic pulse has a greater in the Alagoas 423
portion, with the creation of more accommodation (related to tectonic pulse) than in 424
the Sergipe portion. Furthermore, in contrast with well A, the overfilled systems tract 425
succession in the Alagoas portion is poorly developed, composed by alternating 426
distal deposits (prodelta, distal delta front) with proximal delta plain deposits, which 427
suggests that the progradational phase (FST) did not fill completely the available 428
accommodation space. This can be explained by a fast base-level rise (strong pulse 429
of tectonic subsidence) followed by prolonged tectonic stillstand during the tectonic 430
quiescence (Martins Neto & Catuneanu, 2009, in press). 431
6.4. Sequence 4 432
With a thickness of 24.5 to 74.5 m, this sequence begins suddenly with a 433
retrogradational trend with the deposition of thin lacustrine mudstones overlying the 434
flooding surface. 435
In Sergipe sub-basin, the transition is less abrupt, with the deposition of trough-436
bedded and massive delta front sandstones overlain by thin lacustrine deposits. A 437
well-defined coarsening-upward succession, mostly composed of bioturbated, 438
massive distal delta front sandstones, overlain by trough cross-bedded proximal delta 439
front sandstones (mouth-bars), represents the filled phase. 440
18
In the Alagoas portion, the gamma-ray profile suggests a filled phase composted 441
of interlayered prodelta and distal to proximal delta front deposits. Overlying this 442
sucession, an abrupt drop in gamma-ray (at depth 1311 m) marks probably the onset 443
of the overfilled phase, with the erosive base of a thick amalgamated distributary 444
channel. In Sergipe, a sharp erosive surface (FS 4) at the base of trough cross-445
bedded conglomerates, overlain by thick amalgamated distributary channel, crevasse 446
splay, and interdistributary bay deposits, points to a change from the filled to 447
overfilled phase. 448
6.5. Sequence 5 449
This sequence is characterized by a remarkable difference in sequence thickness 450
between the two wells. In the Sergipe-sub basin, the very thin sequence (11.9 m 451
thick) shows a retrogradational trend, overlain by only 2 m thick proximal delta front 452
deposits that signals the onset the progradational depositional trend. This succession 453
is followed by thick erosive, massive matrix-supported conglomerates (FS 5). The 454
overfilled phase dominates the depositional sequence, which suggests that the 455
creation of accommodation produced by regional tectonic subsidence (pulse) began 456
to decrease. In contrast, with a thickness of 95.5 m, in the Alagoas portion the 457
depositional sequence is relatively complete. Overlying the flooding surface, the 458
gamma-ray data shows a retrogradational trend that reach its maximum (MFS) in an 459
unrecovered core interval. Overlying the maximum flooding surface, a coarsening-460
upward succession, possibly delta front deposits, characterizes the filled systems 461
tract. At last, thick assemblages of erosive and amalgamated distributary channel 462
sand bodies, interlayered with thin crevasse splay deposits, represent the overfilled 463
phase (OST). 464
6.6. Sequence 6 465
19
This sequence shows many similitudes with the previous sequence. While the 466
overfilled phase clearly dominates a very thin sequence (6.1 m) in the Sergipe 467
portion, the Alagoas portion shows a thick, complete sequence with a thicker 468
succession deposited in the filled phase, indicating a longer period of quiescence. 469
Overlying the flooding surface (SB 5), distal delta deposits covered by prodelta 470
heterolites define the slightly retrogradational trend in the Sergipe portion, abruptly 471
covered by massive and low-angle cross-bedded sandstones interpreted as part of 472
proximal delta front deposits (filled systems tract). A 40 cm thick layer, intensely 473
broken and oxidized, with green and red concretions, and indistinctive bioturbation, 474
forms the top of the sequence (ovrfilled systems tract). This horizon, interpreted as a 475
paleosol (1814,60 m), represents a long hiatus with subaerial exposure, suggesting 476
that at that time, the basin was completely overfilled, with no more sediment input 477
from the sedimentary source. 478
The Alagoas succession, 90 m thick, shows an opposite trend. The sequence 479
begins with rapid creation of accommodation, with a thin retrogradational succession 480
formed by lacustrine and prodelta mudstones overlying the flooding surface. The 481
maximum flooding surface, identified at depth of 1181 m in thick lacustrine 482
mudstones, possibly corresponds to the datum in the 3th-order K35/20 sequence, 483
identified by Borba (2011). The filled sytems tract (57.5 m thick) is mostly composed 484
of gray and black mudstones, interlayered with thin, bioturbated very-fine sandstones 485
deposited in distal delta fronts. The common presence of turbidites interbedded with 486
these deposits suggests a fairly high-slope basin margin and probably high 487
accommodation available, and may mean that sedimentation in that part of the basin 488
was probably still under underfilled conditions (A>>S). Overlying this poorly 489
developed filled phase, the occurrence of very thin, trough cross-bedded 490
conglomerates, slightly erosive, marks the beginning of the overfilled phase, also little 491
20
pronounced. During the overfilled systems tract, thin conglomerates are interlayered 492
with fine-grained, distal delta front and prodelta deposits. This suggests that the 493
basin was potentially still in the filled phase, under more humid conditions, and that 494
repetitive incursion of distributary channels resulted from minor-scale climatic 495
changes. Isotopic data indicated that sedimentation during the Barremian (Buracica 496
local stage) took place under more humid conditions (Chiossi, 1997), which could 497
partially explain the predominance of distal mudstones and a poorly developed 498
progradacional filled-overfilled succession. 499
6.7. Sequence 7 500
This sequence corresponds to the last 3th-order sequence of the Barra de Itiúba 501
Formation. Its thickness varies between 12.3 and 98 m. The basal flooding surface 502
(SB 6) is covered by a retrogradational succession formed by gray mudstones in the 503
Sergipe portion and black lacustrine deposits in the Alagoas portion, suggesting 504
renewed intensity of tectonic subsidence in the Sergipe sub-basin, in comparison 505
with the two previous sequences (low to moderately intensity of tectonic pulse). 506
Consequently, the progradational trend that characterizes the filled systems tract is 507
thicker and better developed, formed by distal delta front, bioturbated sandstones 508
interlayered with prodelta, massive mudstones. 509
In the Alagoas sub-basin, the filled phase is mostly composed of prodelta 510
mudstones, with common distal deltaic incursions. Overlying this interval, the 511
occurrence of highly erosive, amalgamated distributary channel deposits, associated 512
with crevasse splay and interdistributary bay deposits, signals the predominance of 513
the overfilled phase, completing the sequence. In Sergipe, the overfilled phase began 514
with a highly erosive, trough cross-bedded conglomerate, followed by oxidized, low 515
angle cross-bedded sandstones with centimetric coal clasts, interpreted as crevasse 516
splay deposits. 517
21
6.8. Sequence 8 518
This sequence is interpreted as the lithostratigraphic transition between the Barra 519
de Itiúba Formation and the Penedo Formation in the Alagoas portion, and the Rio 520
Pitanga Formation in the Sergipe portion (Borba, 2009, 2011). This incomplete 521
sequence was detailed through core description only in the retrogradacional 522
succession (well A). Abruptly overlying the flooding surface are gray to black prodelta 523
and lacustrine mudstones. Above the maximum flooding surface, the gamma-ray 524
signature (not includin in this work) in the two sections suggests that the rate of 525
sedimentation and occurrence of coarse-grained deposits tend to increase. In 526
Sergipe, this interval was interpreted as a thick succession of distributary channel 527
and fluvial-alluvial channels deposits (Rio Pitanga Formation), and as amalgamated 528
distributary channel deposits in the Alagoas portion (Penedo Formation). 529

7. Tectono-stratigraphic synthesis 531
Sequence 1 represents the onset of the second tectonic pulse (2 th
order) across 532
the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin. Its succession is dominated by overfilled systems tract 533
(OST), characterized by the predominance of coarse-grained deposits, principally 534
composed of erosive distributary channel deposits. This suggests that the available 535
accommodation space created during the tectonic pulse is not even sufficient to 536
“accommodate” the sediment supply, probably produced in great part from the border 537
fault. Unlike the first sequence, Sequence 2 shows a well-defined retrogradational, 538
with deposition of lacustrine sediments onto the flooding surface, suggesting rapid 539
creation of accommodation space with increasing tectonic activity. The filled phase is 540
well developed, forming the bulk of this sequence, composed of a coarsening-upward 541
succession of prodelta deposits progressively covered by delta front sandstones. The 542
22
overfilled phase begins with occurrence of erosive distributary channel deposits (FS 543
2) interlayed with crevasse splay and interdistributary bay deposits. 544
Deposition of Sequence 3 began with a very short retrogradational trend with the 545
abrupt accumulation of deep water black, organic-rich mudstones that cover the 546
flooding surface, suggesting a stronger tectonic pulse linked to increasing tectonic 547
subsidence. The sedimentary succession that represents the filled phase shows a 548
slight coarsening-upward trend, composed of prodelta and distal delta front deposits. 549
In the Alagoas portion, the poorly-developed overfilled systems tract suggests that 550
the available accommodation space was not completely filled, contrary to the Sergipe 551
portion, where the overfilled phase was well developed. This suggests that the 552
tectonic pulses has a greater role in the Alagoas portion, with longer periods of 553
tectonic quiescence between them. 554
Sequence 4 is similar to the previous sequence. It began with a short 555
retrogradational trend that led to the accumulation of lacustrine deposits, followed by 556
a well-defined, thicker progradational trend. The thick filled systems tract in the 557
Sergipe portion points to renewed tectonic activity with border fault reactivation in the 558
Sergipe portion. Meanwhile, in the Alagoas portion, the tectonic activity seems to 559
have stabilized, with less creation of accommodation, as indicated by the coarser-560
grain progradational trend (filled phase) and thick distributary channel deposits of the 561
overfilled phase. 562
There is some evidence of tectonic changes during the deposition of Sequence 5. 563
While in the Alagoas portion this sequence clearly shows rapid creation of 564
accommodation by tectonic pulse, followed by a thick progradational succession 565
(filled and overfilled phase), in the Sergipe portion the sedimentary succession clearly 566
shows decreasing intensity of the tectonic activity. The overfilled systems tract 567
23
predominates, with a very short filled phase covered by thick erosive conglomerates 568
(FS 5), suggesting low accommodation relative to sediment supply (A<<S). 569
This general trend is confirmed during the deposition of Sequence 6. In the 570
Sergipe portion, following the deposition of very thin prodelta heterolites, the filled 571
phase is largely composed of massive, proximal delta front sandstones, covered by 572
paleosol horizon, indicating that the basin was completely overfilled and subject to 573
subaerial exposure with long-term erosion (with probably high-frequency climatic 574
contribution, in more arid conditions). The Alagoas portion, on the other hand, shows 575
evidence of increasing tectonic activity. A very thin retrogradational succession is 576
rapidly covered by a thick, finer-grained progradational succession (filled phase), 577
followed by thin, poorly-developed distributary channel deposits interlayered with 578
distal delta deposits, suggesting an augmentation of available accommodation space 579
by tectonic pulse. 580
The last complete sequence (7) points to renewed tectonic activity (probably of 581
moderate intensity) in the Sergipe portion, as indicated by the deposition of prodelta 582
mudstones, followed by a thicker and more better developed filled systems tract, 583
covered by thin and highly erosive distributary channel and crevasse splay deposits. 584
In the Alagoas portion, the tectonic regime seems to have been even stronger, but 585
with a tendency to decrease. The filled phase is thinner, mostly composed of distal 586
delta deposits. The following overfilled systems tract predominates, with the 587
deposition of interlayered beds of thick conglomerates and fine-grained crevasse 588
splay associated with interdistributary bay deposits. Compared with previous 589
sequences, the dominance of overfilled phase in Sequence 7 is probably due to a 590
combination of tectonic and climatic effects. Sedimentation during the late stages of 591
rift evolution in the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is probably controlled by a decrease of 592
24
tectonic activity (less accommodation space creation), combined with more humid 593
conditions (increase of clastic contributions) (Chiossi, 1997; Borba, 2011). 594
8. Conclusion 595
1. The Barra de Itiúba Formation records the deposition of deltaic and lacustrine 596
sediments accumulated in the syn-rift Sergipe-Alagoas Basin during the second 597
extensional pulse (2 th order) of basin evolution. Facies analysis in wells and outcrops 598
allowed the recognition of 22 facies, grouped into seven facies associations that 599
characterize different depositional environments: (i) distributary channel (braided and 600
meandering), (ii) crevasse splay, (iii) interdistributary bay, (iv) proximal delta front, (v) 601
distal delta front, (vi) prodelta, and (vii) lacustrine. 602
2. The application of Martins-Neto & Catuneanu (2009, in press) rift sequence 603
stratigraphic model in the two well sections allowed the identification of seven 604
complete 3 th
order depositional sequences bounded by flooding surface (sequence 605
boundary). 606
3. All the sequences initiated with a relatively thin retrogradational succession 607
representing the ‘instantaneous’ creation of accommodation linked to 3 th
order 608
tectonic pulse (underfilled phase, A>S). Then, a long progradational trend (filled 609
systems tract), describing a coarsening-upward deltaic succession, is filling the 610
available accommodation (filled phase, A<S then A>S in proximal delta front). 611
Starting onto the “filling surface” (FS), the last portion (overfilled systems tract), 612
composed of erosive amalgamated distributary channels associated with crevasse 613
splay and interdistributary bay deposits, characterize the “overfilled phase”, when the 614
accommodation space is not sufficient relative to sediment supply. 615
4. The Sergipe portion is thinner (181m thick), mostly composed of proximal deposits 616
(delta front, deltaic plain), and was deposited during a relatively low local tectonic 617
regime. In contrast, the thicker Alagoas portion (655 m), mostly composed of distal 618
25
deposits (lacustrine to delta front), show evidences of higher tectonic subsidence with 619
high rate of accommodation, combined with sedimentation in more humid conditions. 620

A B S T R A C T 15
Recent work in two wells (A & B) has defined seven stratigraphic sequences in the 16
Barra de Itiúba Formation (Hauterivian-Barremian). Systems tracts identified in each 17
sequence (Underfilled, Filled, Overfilled) represent different tectono-sedimentary 18
histories and reflect variations in the rate of creation/destruction of accommodation 19
space and sediment supply (A/S ratio). Comparative analysis of grain size, porosity, 20
and permeability between the sedimentary succession in wells A and B allowed the 21
description of numerous reservoirs (23) and non-reservoirs zones (3). High-quality 22
reservoirs are mostly represented by thick, amalgamated distributary-channel 23
conglomerates and channel-fill sandstones, deposited during the Overfilled systems 24
2
tracts (OST). Fairly to very porous channel-fill bar conglomerates frequently show 25
very good permeabilities (>100 mD). Rare, thin deep-lacustrine turbidites deposited 26
during the Filled systems tracts (FST) show good to very good properties. During the 27
FST in the Sergipe Sub-basin (well A), fine-grained, proximal bars deposited in the 28
delta fronts show low to good permeability. Poor-quality reservoir zones, often 29
showing impervious layers (0 <1 mD), are mostly formed by very-fine sandstones 30
and heterolites in distal delta fronts. Poor reservoir properties are also found in highly 31
bioturbated and deformed silty-mudstones deposited in overbank settings (crevasse 32
splay, interdistributary bay), mostly associated with thin erosive distributary channels. 33
Keywords: Syn-rift deposits, lacustrine delta, sequence stratigraphy, grain size, 34
porosity and permeability, reservoir properties. 35
1. Introduction 36
Syn-rift deposits may bear substantial hydrocarbon resources. During tectonic 37
extension, half-graben geometry (Rosendalh et al., 1986) and restricted sub-basins 38
(Huc et al., 1990) favor the accumulation of organic-rich lacustrine sediments, 39
frequently impermeable (0 <0.1 mD) that comprise source rocks; as well as porous, 40
permeable deltaic conglomerates and sandstones that may form reservoirs. Two syn-41
rift, correlative successions can originate from the same extension event (through a 42
tectonic pulse or hanging-wall fault reactivation), but present completely different 43
infilling histories, relative to accommodation and sediment supply. 44
The Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is a mature oil-field basin (Borba et al.,, 2011), 45
mostly explored in the Alagoas Sub-basin (Furado and Pilar Fields), but less known 46
in the deeper Sergipe Sub-basin (Fig. 1). The Barra de Itiúba Formation was 47
deposited during syn-rift extension of the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin (Schaller, 1969; 48
Chiossi, 1997, 2005; Campos-Neto et al., 2007; Borba et al., 2011). A recent study 49
3
aiming that provided a reappraisal of its tectono-stratigraphic evolution identified and 50
described seven third-order sequences in two wells (A and B), sub-dividing the 51
sequences in systems tracts (Underfilled, Filled, Overfilled) that reflect variations in 52
accommodation relative to sediment supply (Courivaud et al., 2018, in revision). 53
Petrographic studies in well A (Rodrigues & Goldberg, 2014) identified numerous 54
reservoir petrofacies, representing different qualities, and showed that mechanical 55
compaction and cementation by kaolinite and dolomite reduced primary porosity, 56
while precipitation of quartz overgrowths increased preservation of primary porosity. 57
In well B, results from a study on diagenetic patterns and processes in the Barra de 58
Itiúba arkoses (Baumhardt, 2015) showed that porosity loss resulted from 59
cementation by ferruginous calcite and discontinuous quartz overgrowths, and 60
mechanical and chemical compaction. 61
Despite the progress on understanding the Barra de Itiúba Formation, little is 62
known about the relation between detailed stratigraphy (lithofacies and facies 63
associations) and reservoir quality (porosity and permeability). The main objective of 64
this study is to reveal where the best potential hydrocarbon reservoirs are within the 65
high-resolution stratigraphic framework of the syn-rift Barra de Itiúba Formation. Our 66
analysis is a comparative study between two stratigraphically-equivalent sections in 67
the Sergipe (well A) and Alagoas (well B) sub-basins that show very different tectono-68
sedimentary fillings. The analysis of grain size, porosity, and permeability data 69
according to lithofacies, facies associations, and systems tracts aims at explaining 70
similarities or major differences in reservoir properties (porosity and permeability), 71
and identifying, detailing and quantifying reservoir quality. 72
Include Figure. 1 73
It is important to highlight, however, that the two studied well sections have 74
many un-recovered portions which have been interpreted only through gamma-ray 75
4
data. The studied succession in the Sergipe Sub-basin (Well A) is 163.15 m thick, of 76
which about 22.2 m (or 13%) were un-recovered (Fig. 2). The studied succession in 77
the Alagoas Sub-basin (Well B) is much thicker in total (620.1 m), but about 270.4 m 78
(or 44%) of the succession is un-recovered (Fig. 2). Thus, our study is based on 79
approximately 87% (in Well A) and 57% (in Well B) of the total sedimentary record of 80
the Barra de Itiúba Formation. In the Alagoas Sub-basin, many systems tracts were 81
defined only by vertical variations in the gamma-ray signature, without the proper 82
identification of key stratigraphic surfaces. For this reason, our comparative analysis 83
of grain size, porosity, and permeability in the two wells was carried out according to 84
systems tracts (Underfilled, Filled, and Overfilled systems tract). A summary of the 85
facies analysis and third-order sequence stratigraphic framework used in this study is 86
provided below. For more detail, please refer to the detailed paper (Courivaud et al, 87
2018, in revision). 88
Include Figure. 2 89
2. Geological setting and stratigraphic framework 90
The Sergipe-Alagoas Basin, located on the Brazilian eastern margin (Fig. 1A), 91
covers an onshore area of 13,000 km² of sediments and an offshore portion of 92
32,760 km² (Mohriak, 2003). This basin was formed as a result from the evolution of 93
an asymmetric rift, elongated in a NNE/SSW direction (Feijó, 1994; Campos Neto et 94
al., 2007). Structurally, it consists of a southeastward-dipping half-graben (Souza-95
Lima, 2002), separated in two parts by the Japoatã-Penedo High: the Sergipe and 96
the Alagoas sub-basins (Fig. 1A) (Feijó, 1994). The basin can be subdivided into 97
blocks (or tectonic compartments) limited by large normal faults (Fig. 1B). The high 98
dispersion on direction and orientation of normal faults is responsible for the complex 99
tectonic history of the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin. 100
5
In each compartment, the various tectonic phases have directly conditioned the 101
sedimentary filling of regional depocenters. Consequently, different tectonic styles 102
resulted in different sedimentary records in the Sergipe and the Alagoas Basins, and 103
a rather complex spatial distribution of chrono and lithostratigraphic units (Aquino & 104
Lana, 1990). Nonetheless, the stratigraphic record in the Sergipe-Alagoas Basin is 105
the most complete succession among the Brazilian continental margins, reflecting 106
different phases of subsidence (Table 1): Syneclisis (Carboniferous-Permian); Pre-107
Rift Supersequence (Tithonian-Berriasian); Rift Supersequence (Berriasian-Aptian) 108
(Bizzi et al., 2003). The studied succession belongs to the Rift Supersequence. 109
According to Campos Neto et al (2007), the Rift Supersequence, beginning 142 Ma 110
ago (Berriasian), is divided in different sub-sequences, from base to top called K10-111
K20, K34-K36, K38, and K40 (Feijó, 1994; Chiossi, 2005; Campos Neto et al., 2007; 112
Borba et al., 2011). The accumulation of the lacustrine deposits of the Feliz Deserto 113
Formation (K10-K20) marks the beginning of the syn-rift succession. The focus of this 114
study is the fluvio-deltaic and lacustrine deposits of the Barra de Itiúba and Penedo 115
Formations (K34-K36) overlying the Feliz Deserto Formation. They correspond to the 116
second tectonic pulse of the syn-rift phase (2) (Table 1), characterized by the 117
establishment of graben and/or half-graben systems (Chagas et al., 2003). 118
Include Table. 1 119
In recent stratigraphic studies (Courivaud et al, 2018, in revision), the Barra de 120
Itiúba Formation (K34-K36) was subdivided into seven third-order sequences that 121
included 18 facies (Table 2), grouped into seven facies associations that characterize 122
different depositional environments: (i) distributary channel (braided and 123
meandering), (ii) crevasse splay, (iii) interdistributary bay, (iv) proximal delta front, (v) 124
distal delta front, (vi) prodelta, and (vii) lacustrine. 125
6
The Barra de Itiúba Formation is composed dominantly of quartzose 126
sandstones (Sh, Sl, St, Sr, Sd, Sb), mudstones (Fr, Fd, Fl, Fb, Fm, P, C), sandy 127
conglomerates (Gmm, Gt), and subordinately heterolites (Hr, H). Texturally, the 128
sandstones are very fine- to coarse-grained (mostly very fine- to fine-grained), 129
moderately- to well-sorted, with sub-angular to rounded grains. Quartz granules are 130
common in massive sandstones (Sm) and near the base of cross-bedded sets (St). 131
Mudstones are commonly greenish and bioturbed (Fb), black-organic-rich (C), 132
massive and gray (Fm), and, less commonly laminated (Fl) and fluidized (Fd). 133
Conglomerates are massive, matrix-supported (Gmm), and trough cross-bedded 134
(Gt), with sub-angular to sub-rounded granules to pebbles (mostly granules). 135
Compositionally, the gravel is dominated by quartz and mud intraclasts, with 136
occasionally feldspar grains and rock fragments. Well A is characterized by the 137
dominance of coarse-grained lithofacies, compared with Well B, in which the 138
proportion between coarse- and fine-grained lithofacies is about the same. 139
Distributary channel (braided and meandering) facies association is 140
characterized by Gmm, Gt, Sh, Sl, St, (Sr) lithofacies, crevasse splay by Sb, Sm, 141
(Sr), (Sd), interdistributary bay Fb, (Fm), (Fl), (P), proximal delta front Sd, St, (Sl), 142
distal delta front Sr, Sb, Hr, (H), prodelta H, Fr, Fd, Fm,(Fl), and lacustrine C, Fm, Fl. 143
The vertical facies succession and the thickness of each facies association differs 144
between wells A and B and the outcrop area. Representative vertical logs, along with 145
the description and interpretation for each facies association in both wells are 146
detailed in Courivaud et al. (2018, in revision). 147
The application of rift sequence stratigraphic model by Martins-Neto & 148
Catuneanu (2009) allowed the recognition that every sequence initiated with a 149
relatively thin, retrogradational succession representing the ‘instantaneous’ creation 150
of accommodation linked to third-order tectonic pulses (underfilled systems tract, 151
7
A>S) (Courivaud et al., 2018). It is followed by a thick progradational trend that forms 152
a coarsening-upward deltaic succession, filling the available accommodation space 153
(filled systems tract, A<S then A>S). The “filling surface” (FS) separates the top of 154
the filled systems tract from the overfilled systems tract, which is composed of 155
erosive-based, amalgamated distributary channels associated with crevasse splay 156
and interdistributary bay deposits, formed when the accommodation space is not 157
enough for the sediment supply. The Sergipe portion is thinner (165.05 m thick), 158
mostly composed of proximal (delta front, deltaic plain) deposits accumulated during 159
a local, relatively low tectonic regime. In contrast, the thicker Alagoas portion (620.1 160
m), mostly composed of distal (lacustrine to delta front) deposits, shows evidence of 161
higher tectonic subsidence with high accommodation rate, combined with 162
sedimentation in more humid conditions. 163
Include Table. 2 164
3. Methods 165
Characterization of potential reservoir zones of the syn-rift Barra de Itiúba 166
Formation in two correlative sections (wells A and B) was achieved by comparison 167
and integration of detailed lithological description (grain size, facies, facies 168
associations), sequence stratigraphy (systems tracts), and reservoir properties 169
(porosity and permeability). Studied wells were described in detail, resulting in the 170
construction on lithologic logs at 1:100 scale. Facies analysis was based on 171
lithofacies description following Miall (1978), including color, texture (grain size, 172
sorting, and roundness), sedimentary structures, and fossil content, aided by gamma-173
ray log signature. The recognition of facies and facies associations, combined with 174
the identification of major stratigraphic surfaces (maximum flooding surfaces, flooding 175
8
surfaces, erosional surfaces, paleosols) allowed the identification of systems tracts 176
and third-order stratigraphic sequences. 177
Evaluation of reservoir quality took into account porosity and permeability. 178
Porosity values define pore-volume available space that can contain potential 179
migrated hydrocarbon, and it was estimated by the combination of density and 180
neutron logs. Evaluation of porosity quality was done by using recent conventional 181
range of porosity (Tiab & Donaldson, 2012) in petroleum reservoirs: 0-5 % 182
(Negligible); 5-10 % (Poor); 10-15 % (Fair); 15-20 % (Good); 20-25 % (Very-Good); 183
25-30 % (Excellent). Permeability defines the ability of fluids to flow through porous 184
rock, and it was obtained by lag injection tests in cores. The unit of permeability is the 185
Darcy, generally noted millidarcy (mD) because dimensions are very often too large 186
to be conventional in reservoir characterization. For reservoir quality, conventional 187
measurements of permeability values used are: 0<1 mD (Impervious or 188
Impermeable); 1-10 mD (Poor to Fair); 10-100 mD (Good); 10-1000 (Very-Good). 189
Sample distribution at different depths allowed to subdivision in several beds 190
with at least one value of porosity and one of permeability. Identification of individual 191
beds was done by the recognition of abrupt vertical changes in grain size that defined 192
more or less precisely the bed base and top. In general, each bed is characterized by 193
one or two dominant lithofacies, which was the second criterion used to estimate bed 194
thickness and separate reservoir zones within the initial bed subdivision. Next, the 195
beds identified were grouped in several reservoir zones, ideally capped by an 196
impervious thick bed. Bed numbering was based on the corresponding systems 197
tracts (U for ‘underfilled’, F for ‘filled’, and O for ‘overflled’) and order of apparition 198
from the base. 199
Description of potential reservoir zones was performed in this way to evaluate, in 200
as much detail as possible (grain size, bedding, sedimentary structures, presence of 201
9
mud intraclasts, fluidization, bioturbation), why some reservoir zones are low quality, 202
whereas others show very good to excellent properties. 203
4. Grain size in relation to systems tracts 204
The comparative grain-size analysis between wells A and B was based on the 205
defined systems tracts (Fig. 3), described below. By measuring the cumulative 206
thickness of the sedimentary succession for each systems tract, the results show that 207
the Filled systems tract (FST) dominates the sedimentary record in both wells A and 208
B (48.41% and 53.56%, respectively). 209
4.1. Underfilled systems tract (UST) 210
4.1.1. Description 211
With a total thickness of 27.05 m (18.94%), the UST in well A is dominated by 212
deposition of very fine to fine (47.69 %) deltaic sandstones, lacustrine mudstones 213
(31.05%) and silts (17.93%). The coarser sediments, represented by medium-to-214
coarse sandstones and conglomerates, are insignificant to non-existent (3.33% and 215
0%). 216
With thickness of 66.16 m in total (19.77%), the UST in well B shows a clear 217
dominance of blackish lacustrine clays (66.16%), and subordinately prodeltaic silts 218
(20.1%). The proportion of fine sandstones is much lower than in well A (11.86%), 219
and coarser sandstones and conglomerates (1.74% and 0.14%, respectively) are 220
almost non-existent. 221
4.1.2. Interpretation 222
The major difference in particle size between wells A and B could be partly 223
explained by the intensity of the initial tectonic pulse and consequent creation of 224
accommodation. The Underfilled systems tract represents the moment of abrupt 225
deepening of the basin resulting from renewed tectonic activity along the hanging-226
wall normal fault (border fault). This deepening phase is accompanied by the rapid 227
10
creation of accommodation space, with base level rise of the lake. Thus, a significant 228
tectonic pulse would result in sedimentation dominated by deep lacustrine, clayey 229
mudstones, even black, organic-rich shales. This trend occurs regularly only in well 230
B, frequently forming thick, organic-rich mudstones that are potentially source rocks. 231
In well A, sedimentation is largely dominated by distal to prodeltaic delta-front 232
sandstones and siltstones (a cumulative 65.8%), often forming thin, metric 233
successions, accompanied be lacustrine massive mudstones. This is quite the 234
opposite of what occurs in the Alagoas Sub-basin (well B), where sedimentation of 235
lacustrine mudstones is predominant (66.16% in well B vs. 31.05% in well A). The 236
greater degree of bioturbation in well A than in B suggests sedimentation in a more 237
oxygenated, shallow-lake environment in the Sergipe Sub-basin. 238
The difference in total thickness of the Barra de Itiúba Formation in wells A and 239
B (163.155 m vs. 620.1 m) seems to indicate that the tectonic activity is higher near 240
the Furado depocenters in the Alagoas Sub-basin (well B), resulting in the creation of 241
more accommodation space during the Underfilled systems tract. Conversely, in the 242
uplifted region of Atalaia High in the Sergipe Sub-basin (well A), the sedimentary 243
record already shows evidence of a transition to the subsequent Filled systems tract 244
(FST), probably with smaller tectonic offsets (low creation of accommodation space), 245
as indicated by the largely deltaic sedimentation. 246
Include Figure. 3 247
4.2. Filled systems tract (FST) 248
4.2.1. Description 249
With a total thickness of 69.15 m (48.41%), well A is largely dominated by very 250
fine to fine-grained sandstones (65.55%), largely deposited in distal to proximal delta 251
front bars. Commonly sand bodies rapidly covered siltstones (17.21%) and greenish 252
prodeltaic mudstones (12%), which generally dominate the initial FST. As in the UST, 253
11
coarse-grained sandstones and conglomerates are greatly subordinate, although 254
more abundant (4.34% and 0.43%, respectively). 255
In well B, the cumulative thickness of FST in the sedimentary succession is 256
187.15 m (53.56%). In contrast to the uplifted region (well A), sedimentation in well B 257
is predominantly thick, lacustrine and prodeltaic siltstones and mudstones (a 258
cumulative of 74.8%). These fine-grained sediments are often intercalated with 259
heterolites (Hr, H) and sandstones (Sr, Sb), mostly deposited in distal bars of delta 260
front and prodelta. The proximal bars (Sd, St) described in well A represent the end 261
of the FST, but they rarely occur in the Alagoas Sub-basin (well B). 262
4.2.2. Interpretation 263
Grain-size distribution indicates major differences between the two 264
compartments, in terms of accommodation space and depositional environments. In 265
well A, the relatively thin sedimentary fill and the recurrence of fine sandstones 266
deposited in proximal deltaic fronts indicate a relatively low sediment input in a 267
relatively shallow basin, rapidly filled by delta progradation. This is the expected 268
continuation of the previous phase (UST), with progressively lower tectonic activity 269
accompanied by lower accommodation creation. FST in well B is generally gradual 270
(slightly coarsening-upward) and much thicker in total (cumulative 187.15 m). The 271
abundance of fine-grained prodelta-lake deposits (140.1 m), frequently interbedded 272
with very thin sandstones deposited in distal bars point to more distal settings, 273
associated with larger accommodation space under high lake base-level. The basin 274
was progressively filled with sandy sediments resulting from repeated delta front 275
discharges, often forming subtle, thick coarsening-upward successions, from deep 276
lacustrine black mudstones to distal to proximal delta front sandstones. Renewed 277
tectonic activity (pulses) is stronger near the Furado depocenters (well B), and 278
therefore the FST in this region also shows a trend compatible with the tectono-279
12
stratigraphic evolution in distal environments (deep lake to distal delta front), 280
reflecting low-energy regimes in locations with more accommodation space to be 281
filled. 282
4.3. Overfilled systems tract (OST) 283
This systems tract represents the last phase of sedimentation in each of the 284
seven third-order stratigraphic sequences (Courivaud et al., 2018 in revision). The 285
passage from Filled to Overfilled systems tract is ideally marked by the recognition of 286
a major erosive surface (SE), representing the basal incision of distributary channels 287
eroding down into proximal delta front sandstones. In the OST, accommodation 288
space may or may not be "drastically" limited, depending whether the basin had been 289
mostly filled with distal deltaic deposits during FST, with no additional creation of 290
accommodation space. In this case, the basin is subjected to widespread erosion, 291
expressed by frequent channel migrations and implantation of greenish to reddish, 292
very bioturbated fine deposits of interdistributary bay, and exceptionally, paleosol 293
horizons. 294
4.3.1. Description 295
The thinner section in the Sergipe Sub-basin (well A) is 46.65 m thick in total, 296
which represents about 33% of the sedimentary succession of the Barra de Itiúba 297
Formation. Deposits are mainly composed of very fine to fine-grained sandstones 298
(44.8%), very often associated with channel-fill (Sl, St, Sr) and associated crevasse 299
splay (Sd, Sm, Sb) deposits. Channel-fill conglomerates (Gt, Gmm), deposited at the 300
beginning of the OST, are much more common than in previous two systems tracts 301
(16.18%). These thin (1-2 m thick) conglomerates are often very erosive, rapidly 302
followed by channel-fill sandstones. Channel thin successions are overlain by 303
bioturbated overbank (Fm, Fb), mostly crevasse splay and interdistributary bay 304
13
deposits. Delta plain environments are represented in the majority of fine (clay-silt) 305
deposits in the studied successions (cumulative 13.5 m, or 28.94%). 306
In the Furado depocenter at Alagoas Sub-basin (well B), the OST is less 307
representative (26.67%) than in the Sergipe Sub-basin, despite the greater 308
cumulative thickness in the former well (93.25 m). Grain-size data shows a 309
dominance of very fine to fine (33.83%) and medium to very coarse (25.68%) 310
sandstones. Channel conglomerates (Gt, Gmm) are less representative (10.67%) 311
than in well A, while the proportion of clay-silt deposits is similar (29.81%). However, 312
unlike well A, well B organic-rich mudstones account for half (50.68%) of the OST, 313
frequently intercalated with fine-grained fluvial successions associated with overbank 314
deposits. Medium-to-coarse sandstones are largely associated with channel-fill sand 315
bars (St), but also with crevasse splay deposits (Sd, Sm). Very fine to fine 316
sandstones mostly comprise channel-fill (Sl, St, Sr) deposits. 317
4.3.2. Interpretation 318
The comparison of grain-size data in the two wells highlights the differences in 319
sedimentary processes, depositional environments, and remaining accommodation 320
space between the two compartments. In the Atalaia High (Sergipe Sub-basin, well 321
A), river systems were very erosive and composed of generally thinner (<1 m) 322
distributary-channel, basal conglomerates, abruptly overlain by overbank deposits 323
dominated by frequent crevasse splay and green-reddish interdistributary bay 324
deposits. In the Furado region (Alagoas Sub-basin, well B), distributary channels 325
display slightly finer, more homogeneous grain sizes, and river systems were 326
aggradational, forming much thicker amalgamated fluvial bars that reflect the filling of 327
a greater accommodation space. The numerous incursions of distal delta fronts and 328
the abundance of lacustrine deposits signals the availability of still considerable 329
accommodation space. From a tectonic-only point of view, this may be a 330
14
consequence of the stronger initial tectonic pulse in the Alagoas Sub-basin that led to 331
a large accommodation, allowing the establishment of long-lived, thick fluvial 332
successions. 333
5. Porosity and permeability in relation to grain size and systems tracts 334
5.1. Underfilled systems tract (UST) 335
The UST is the one with the least samples with porosity and permeability 336
values (Fig. 4), and thus the comparative results discussed below may not be 337
representative of this systems tract. In well A, most of porosity data comes from very 338
fine to fine-grained sandstones of distal to proximal delta front deposits (73.17% in 339
total). Average porosity of the UST is higher in well B than in well A (12.19%, against 340
10.68% in the latter). In both sections, average porosity does not seem to increase 341
with increasing grain size. In the Sergipe Sub-basin (well A), the best porosity values 342
are found in medium-grained sandstones of proximal delta front deposits (12.13%), 343
while in the Alagoas Sub-basin (well B), prodelta siltstones (13.2%) and interbedded 344
very fine-grained sandstones (13.16%) show the highest values. In both sections, 345
average horizontal permeability (kH) values are very low. In well A, only 9 samples 346
had porosity and permeability values. In those, prodelta siltstones show fair values 347
(8.0 mD), while very-fine sandstones are very poorly permeable (1.89 mD). 348
Conversely, the best permeability in well B is recorded in fine-grained sandstones 349
(13.98 mD), whereas deep-lacustrine mudstones and siltstone are impermeable (0.7 350
and 0.1 mD). 351
Include Figure. 4 352
5.2. Filled systems tract (FST) 353
In both sections, most of porosity data was collected in distal to proximal delta 354
front deposits. In well A, very fine to coarse-grained sandstones, interpreted as 355
15
proximal delta front deposits (74. 43 %), show good porosity values (15.36 % and 356
16.84%), but fair permeability (7.19 mD and 10.18 mD). Limited data in lacustrine to 357
prodeltaic mudstones show fair porosity values (12.86 %) and impervious properties 358
(0.6 mD). In well B, very-fine grained sandstones were mostly deposited in distal bars 359
(70.37%), and show fair porosity (11.86%) and good average permeability (19.03 360
mD). Despite the limited data (N=2), lacustrine mudstones have poor porosity (8.9%) 361
and fair permeability (4.55 mD), and prodelta siltstones (N=2) fair porosity (12.4%) 362
and impermeable (0.1 mD). In well A, turbiditic sandstones are medium to coarse-363
grained, with good porosity (19.8%) and very good fluid-flow properties (800 mD). 364
Turbidites in well B are porous (17.4-19.6%), with good permeability (32.3-38.4 mD). 365
5.3. Overfilled systems tract (OST) 366
In this study, the OST contains the most porosity and permeability data, and 367
hence comparative results are more representative. Both sections show equivalent 368
values of average porosity and permeability. In well A, interdistributary bay, 369
bioturbated (Fb) mudstones show lower values of porosity (11.81%), but good to very 370
good average permeability (109.65 mD). On the other hand, well B shows better 371
porosity (16.21%) but poor permeability (3.06 mD). Lower permeability in well A was 372
found in fairly porous crevasse splay siltstones (10.14 mD). Very fine to fine-grained 373
sandstones, interpreted as distributary channel-fill and subordinately crevasse splay 374
deposit, show similarly good porosity in both sections (19.88 and 19.80%), but better 375
permeability in well A than in well B (173.72 mD, against 50.13 mD in the latter). 376
Coarser sandstones in well A, interpreted as distributary channel deposits, show 377
very-good average porosity (24.88%) and permeability (341.89 mD). In well B, 378
coarser sandstones, deposited in distributary channels and crevasse splays, are less 379
porous (16.73%) and less permeable (134.66 mD). Granulose-pebbly conglomerates 380
formed at the base of erosive distributary channels are less porous in well A than in 381
16
well B (14.02%, against 16.45% in the latter), and less permeable (66.03 mD, against 382
313.24 mD in the latter). Disregarding the conglomerates, porosity values in well A 383
show a positive correlation with increasing grain size. In well B, average porosity 384
does not increase with increasing grain size, but permeability does. 385

Porosity and permeability data are not evenly distributed within the sequence 387
stratigraphic framework of the Barra de Itiúba Formation (Tables 3 and 4). In the 388
thinner, but more complete, section in the Sergipe sub-basin (well A, 86.55% of 389
recovery), sequence 5 is the only one with no data on reservoir properties. In the 390
thicker, but less complete, section in the Alagoas Sub-basin (well B, 56.39% of 391
recovery), only sequence 4 has no data on reservoir properties. However, the 392
distribution of porosity and permeability values in well B is much more fragmentary 393
than in well A, which has a fairly even distribution of the data (Figs. 5 and 6). 394

and sample depths in wells A & B can be found in Tables 3 and 4. Overall, the best 399
potential reservoirs (channel deposits) are much more porous in well A (26-31%) 400
than in well B (14-16 %). Individual reservoir zones in each well are discussed below, 401
from base to top. 402

angle cross-bedded sandstones (St, Sl) (O3), representing reactivation of distributary 574
channels. The base shows very good flow properties due to thin conglomerate (215.9 575
mD). The overlaying crevasse splay deposits, composed of massive medium grained 576
sandstones (O4) with oxide concretions, have good porosity (14.5 – 19.9 %), but 577
permeability is poor (0.5 – 7.1 mD). 578
Amalgamated coarse-grained deposits (O5) marks the onset of the second 579
distributary channel belt, with channel deposits represented by poorly-sorted, cross-580
bedded conglomerates and sandstones (Gt, St) that form a thick succession of 3.70 581
m. The erosive basal channel conglomerates are fairly porous (12.2 %), but 582
sandstones can be very porous with very good permeabilities (103.9 – 1709.9 mD). 583
24
The overlying massive coarse-grained sandstones to conglomerates (O6) and thin 584
(0.15 m) massive conglomerate (O7) show very good to excellent permeability values 585
(362 – 1487.8 mD). They are capped by bioturbated, impervious crevasse splay 586
sandstones (O8) that are porous (18.5 %) but poorly permeable (4.2 mD). 587
Thinner (0.90 m) channel deposits with erosive base (O9, O10) mark new 588
channel incursions, overlain by impervious (0.4 mD) crevasse splay deposits (O11). 589
Fluvial deposits are fairly porous to porous (13.8 – 17.1 %) and can shows great 590
values of permeability (1577.1 mD). The top of the OST, largely dominated by thick, 591
amalgamated fluvial deposits, is composed of very thin massive conglomerates with 592
frequent mud intraclasts (<1 cm) (O12), overlain by bioturbated sandstones 593
deposited in crevasse splays. This succession is capped by a major source rock 594
formed by lacustrine, organic-rich mudstones (U1) that form the UST of Sequence 2. 595
Fluid-flow properties characterize U1 as poorly porous (6.7 %) and impervious (0.4 596
mD). 597
Reservoir zone 2 (1589 – 1584 m) 598
Interbedded between prodelta mudstones (Fm) and organic-rich lacustrine 599
mudstones (Fmc), this thin reservoir zone, deposited as part of the UST of Sequence 600
2, is composed of cross-laminated, very fine-grained sandstones (Sr) interbedded 601
with silty-mudstones (U2). They are overlain by trough cross-bedded, medium to fine-602
grained sandstones, highly fluidized and horizontally-laminated fine-grained 603
sandstones (Sh) (U3) interpreted as distributary channel deposits. Both heterolites 604
and sandstones show poor reservoir properties (0.1 mD and 0.1 – 2.4 mD, 605
respectively). 606
Reservoir zone 3 (1567 – 1557 m) 607
Deposited between finely-laminated prodelta mudstones (Fl), this ~ 4 m thick 608
reservoir zone is formed by distal delta front deposits accumulated in the FST of 609
25
Sequence 2. It comprises ripple cross-laminated sandstones with discontinuous mud 610
drapes due to fluidization and mostly bioturbation, strongly bioturbated sandstones 611
(Sb) (F2) and heterolites with flaser bedding, fluidization structures and low-moderate 612
bioturbation (F3). Both F2 and F3 show poor to fair porosity (3.8 – 11.9 %), mostly 613
impervious (0.1 mD). Fluidized heterolites may be very poorly permeable (2.8 mD). 614
The degree of bioturbation grreatly affects porosity and permeability values by 615
decreasing intergranular pore volume and ability of fluid to flow. 616
Reservoir zone 4 (1541 – 1534 m) 617
Like reservoir zone 3, reservoir zone 4 was mostly deposited in distal delta 618
fronts during the FST of Sequence 2. This thin reservoir zone shows many 619
similarities with reservoir zone 3 in terms of facies and fluid-flow characteristics. Thick 620
(3.70 m) ripple-cross laminated, very-fine sandstones with clay laminae disrupted by 621
bioturbation and fluidization (F4) are overlain by bioturbated, very-fine sandstones 622
with coal clasts (<1 cm) (F5). Porosity in laminated sandstones (F5) is very 623
heterogeneous, poor to fairly good (4 – 12.9 %), and permeability is impervious to 624
poor (0.1 – 4.7 mD). The overlying bioturbated sandstones are impervious (0.1 mD). 625
Once again, bioturbation probably had strong impact on porosity and permeability 626
values. 627
Non-reservoir zone 1 (1415 – 1402.5 m) 628
Deposited between laminated and massive prodelta mudstones, this non-629
reservoir zone is mostly represented by the interbedding of distal bar and prodelta 630
deposits formed during the FST of Sequence 3. Ripple cross-laminated, bioturbated 631
sandstones with mud laminae and coal clasts <1 cm (F6) are overlain by prodelta 632
massive mudstones (F7) and cross-laminated sandstones (Sr) deformed by 633
bioturbation and fluidization deposited in distal bars (F8). Near the top, the deltaic 634
succession comprises two stacked layers (F9, F10) of laminated, very fine-grained 635
26
sandstones with discontinuous, fluidized mud drapes. With poor to fair porosity, all 636
layers are impervious (0.1 mD). 637
Reservoir zone 5 (1400 – 1389.10 m) 638
Representing the end of the FST in Sequence 3, this interval is dominated by 639
proximal delta front bar deposits at base. They comprise fine-grained, cross-bedded 640
and fluidized sandstones (St) with mud intraclasts up to 4 cm (F11). Porosity and 641
permeability are good (14.1 – 19.1 % and 169.7 mD). These sandstones are overlain 642
by bioturbated prodelta mudstones (F12) that are poorly pervious (3.8 – 7.1 mD), and 643
cross-laminated sandstones deposited in distal delta fronts (F13), also poorly 644
pervious (5.1 mD). The top FST is composed of thick bioturbated, ripple-cross 645
laminated very fine-grained sandstones (Sr) deposited in distal bars and greenish 646
prodelta mudstones (F14), porous (13.1 %) and fairly permeable (7.2 mD). 647
Reservoir zone 6 (1389.10 – 1383 m) 648
This thin reservoir zone is part of the OST in sequence 3, and it is mostly 649
composed of distributary channel-fill sandstones. Cross-bedded conglomerates (Gt) 650
with mud intraclasts (<5 cm) overlie the erosive base, followed by cross-bedded 651
(O13) and low-angle (O14) medium-grained sandstones. The upper portion of this 652
reservoir zone is composed of low-angle laminated sandstones (Sl), and 653
subordinately horizontally-laminated, bioturbated and fluidized sandstones (Sh, Sd) 654
(O15). The basal channel fill (O13) can be poorly porous (6.5 %) and impervious to 655
fairly permeable (0.3 – 20.4 mD), while laminated sandstones show good porosity 656
(19.3 – 19.8 %) and good permeability (39.6 – 110.3 mD). Lower permeability in the 657
upper sandstones are due to higher degree of bioturbation and fluidization. Stacked 658
layers show impervious to good permeability (0.3 – 59 mD), despite good to very 659
good porosity (16.8 – 22.1 %). Channel-fill sandstones are overlain by overbank 660
deposits composed of porous, bioturbated green siltstones (O16) interbedded with 661
27
very fine-grained sandstones, showing good permeability values (75.3 – 147.5). This 662
succession is capped by lacustrine laminated mudstones (Fl) that belong to the UST 663
of Sequence 4. The remaining systems tracts in Sequence 4 were identified from the 664
gamma-ray signature only because of a thick un-recovered interval in the core (Fig. 665
6). 666
Reservoir zone 7 (1204.5 – 1198.10 m) 667
This reservoir zone is part of OST in Sequence 5, and it shows well-defined 668
coarsening-upward successions formed by delta progradation. The base is marked 669
by prodelta laminated siltstones and thin, bioturbated sandstones (Sb) (O17), 670
overlain by rippled sandstones deposited in distal bars (O18), fluidized, fine-grained 671
sandstones deposited in delta fronts (O19), culminating with trough-cross bedded 672
sandstones deposited in mouth bars (O20). Stacked layers (O17-O20) show good to 673
very good porosity and excellent permeabilities, especially in proximal bar deposits 674
(65.8 – 351.3 mD). 675
Overlying proximal mouth-bar deposits, slightly erosive conglomerates with 676
moderate fluidization (O21) marks the onset of a distributary channel system 677
composed of trough cross-bedded and ripple cross-laminated fine sandstones (St, 678
Sr) (O22), mostly deformed by bioturbation and fluidization. Conglomerates show 679
good porosity and pervious properties (21.1% and 70.1 mD), while sandstones are 680
fairly pervious (11.9 mD). 681
The channel-fill succession is overlain by crevasse splay deposits composed 682
of slightly fluidized very fine-grained sandstones (O23), and green, highly bioturbated 683
mudstones (O24) deposited in overbanks. Crevasse splay deposits are porous (17.3 684
%) and pervious (70.8 mD), while overbank deposits are impermeable (4%, 0.1 mD), 685
serving as a local cap rock. 686
Reservoir zone 8 (1198.10 – 1191.30 m) 687
28
This reservoir zone, formed by distributary channel deposits that are part of 688
the OST in Sequence 5, is composed of stacked (0.80 m) trough cross-bedded 689
conglomerates withquartz granules and mud intraclasts (<1 cm). The basal 690
conglomerates (O25) show well defined cross-stratification and very good 691
permeability value (339.2 mD), while the overlying conglomerates are incipiently 692
cross-stratified and abundant mud intraclasts (O26), and fairly permeable (13.7 mD). 693
The overlying channel-fill deposits include ripple-laminated very-fine to fine-grained 694
sandstones (O27), incipient cross-bedded, fluidized sandstones (O28), thicker 695
(1.60m), low-angle laminated, fine to medium sandstones (Sh) interbedded with 696
cross-stratified, locally fluidized sandstones with mm-cm coal laminae (O29). The top 697
of channel-fill deposits comprise incipient cross-bedded sandstones (O30), with 698
variable degrees of fluidization (O31, O32). Channel-fill sandstones (O27- O32) show 699
overall very good porosity values (~20-21%), with fair to very good permeability (5.7 700
– 129.6 mD). Overbank deposits composed of impermeable, bioturbated green 701
siltstones (O33) acting as a cap rock. 702
Reservoir zone 9 (1190.80- 1189 m) 703
This thin reservoir zone comprises a channel-fill succession of OST in 704
Sequence 5. The erosive base is covered by thin (0.10 m) trough cross-bedded 705
conglomerates and fining-upward sandstones (St, Sh, Sr) (O34). Porosity is very 706
good (21.2 – 21.7 %) and permeability is good to very good (63.4 – 180.9 mD). The 707
overlying lacustrine organic-rich, laminated mudstones (Flc) are part of the UST in 708
Sequence 6 and act as cap and potential source rocks. 709
Reservoir zone 10 (1117 – 1108.2 m) 710
This thin reservoir zone is part of the OST in Sequence 6, mostly deposited in 711
distal environments (prodelta, lacustrine), overlain by thin and rare delta plain 712
succession (distributary channel and overbank deposits). Lacustrine black, organic-713
29
rich mudstones (O35) are overlain by thick (1.60 m), massive, bioturbated 714
sandstones and thin planar cross-bedded sandstones (O36). This succession is 715
overlain by massive and laminated greenish mudstones (Fm, Fl) forming silt-mud 716
heterolites (O37), deposited in interdistributary bays. Crevasse splay sandstones 717
(O36) are very porous (21.3 -22 %) and poorly permeable (2.3 – 4.8 mD), while the 718
permeability of mudstones is much lower (1.4 mD). 719
Reservoir zone 11 (1095.7 – 1092.7 m) 720
This reservoir zone is part of the initial FST in Sequence 7, and comprises very 721
thin, impervious (4.7%, 0.1 mD) gray, lacustrine mudstones (F15) overlain by very 722
fine to fine-grained trough cross-bedded sandstones (St), interpreted as lacustrine 723
turbidites (F16). Impervious, black organic-rich mudstones (Fmc) overlie the 724
turbidites. Despite the reduced thickness (~30 cm), turbidites are porous (17.4 – 19.6 725
%) and show good permeability (32.3 – 38.4 mD). The two impervious lacustrine 726
layers that bound the turbidites are potential source rocks in Sequence 7. 727
Reservoir zone 12 (1038 – 1030) 728
This reservoir zone is part of the OST in Sequence 7 at the top of the Barra de 729
Itiúba Formation, and comprises channel-fill and overbank deposits. Crevasse splay 730
deposits are composed of bioturbated siltstones with discontinuous mud laminae 731
(O38) that are fairly permeable (8 mD), capped by thin organic-rich mudstones. They 732
are overlain by distributary channel deposits that include low-angle and trough cross-733
bedded, planar and cross-laminated medium-grained sandstones (Sl, St, Sh, Sr) 734
(O39), very thin granulose to pebbly conglomerates (O40), thin sandstones and 735
overbank deposits (Fm). The overlying coarse-grained package includes thin trough 736
cross-bedded conglomerates with quartz granules (Gt) (O41) and horizontally-737
laminated medium-grained sandstones (Sh) (O42). Thin (0.20 m), organic-rich 738
mudstones (Fmc) interpreted as interdistributary bay deposits are overlain by cross-739
30
bedded to massive conglomerates (O43), very-coarse sandstone to conglomeratic 740
sandstones with incipient trough cross-bedding (O44) and the topmost cross-bedded, 741
bioturbated conglomerates (O45), interpreted as amalgamated channel-fill deposits. 742
The top of the succession comprises thick crevasse splay bioturbated sandstones 743
(Sb) and heterolites (Hb). Porosity values in conglomerates show good to very good 744
quality (15.2 – 25.4 %), with homogeneous and good permeabilities (35.7 – 68.7 745
mD). The topmost bioturbated channel-fill deposit (O45) shows lower permeability 746
values (0.1 – 16 mD). 747

7. Conclusion 749
1. A detailed study of the syn-rift Barra de Itiuba Formation allowed to compare two 750
stratigraphically equivalent sections (well A and B) in different portions of the 751
Sergipe-Alagoas Basin in terms of systems tracts with facies associations. With 752
about 87% recovery (142.85 m), the thinner succession (well A) is located in the 753
Atalaia High (Sergipe Sub-basin), whereas with only about 56% recovery (346.7 m), 754
well B is located in the Furado depocenters (Alagoas Sub-basin). 755
2. In both areas, the sedimentary record comprises mostly Filled systems tract (FST 756
48% in well A and 54% in well B), followed by Overfilled systems tract (OST 33% and 757
27% in wells A and B, respectively), thinner Underfilled systems tracts (UST 19% and 758
20% in wells A and B, respectively). 759
3. In the Sergipe Sub-basin (well A), the syn-rift sedimentation is mostly composed 760
of proximal to distal bars of delta front (46%) largely deposited in FST, and by delta 761
plain deposits composed of superimposed distributary channel bars (15%) 762
associated with overbank (17%). Distal lake deposits, mostly in UST, are poorly 763
represented (21%). In the Alagoas Sub-basin (well B), prodelta (30%) and lacustrine 764
31
(25%) deposits dominate the succession, followed by delta front distal bars (21%). 765
This difference may be due to increased subsidence and accommodation created by 766
tectonic pulses in well B in relation to well A, although it should be noted that the 767
sedimentary record in well B is incomplete and hence part of the interpretation was 768
based on the gamma-ray signature. 769
4. Grain-size distribution according to systems tracts in the two sections shows major 770
differences. During UST in the basin, accumulation of sand is predominant in well A 771
(48%), while in well B mostly lacustrine clays are preserved (66%). The subsequent 772
FST maintains the same pattern: well A comprises mostly fine to very fine-grained 773
sandstones (66%) deposited in proximal delta bars (56%), and well B is still 774
dominated by fine-grained sediments (42% siltstones and 32% mudstones) deposited 775
in deeper lacustrine environments (68%). OST is characterized by a dominance of 776
coarse-grained distributary channel deposits, and subordinately crevasse splay. 777
Wells A and B show equivalent proportions of silty-mudstones deposited in overbank 778
areas (29% and 30%, respectively). Distributary channels are common in well A 779
(47%), with conglomerates (16%) and channel-fill and crevasse splay fine 780
sandstones (45%). In well B, the proportion of medium to coarse-grained sandstones 781
is higher (26%), mostly associated to distributary channel deposits. 782
5. Porosity and permeability data were analyzed by systems tracts, in relation with 783
grain size and facies associations. In UST, porosity does not increase with grain size, 784
and average porosity is fair in both sections (11% and 12%). Permeability in well A is 785
better in prodelta siltstones (8.0 mD), while sandstones are poorly permeable (1.89 786
mD). Conversely, in well B sandstones show fair permeability (13.98 mD), while 787
deep-lacustrine silty-mudstones show impervious properties (0.7; 0.1 mD). 788
Impervious lacustrine mudstones are thicker and frequently organic-rich in well B, 789
often forming source rocks, and sometimes acting as reservoir cap rock. In FST, 790
32
porosity and permeability data were mainly collected in delta front sandstones. In well 791
A, distal to proximal bars sandstones (74%) are porous (15.36% and 16.84%) but 792
fairly permeable (7.19 mD and 10.18 mD). In well B, distal bars (70%) are fairly 793
porous (12%) but present good average permeability (19%). OST shows better 794
porosity and permeability values in channel-fill conglomerate deposits. In well A, the 795
best reservoir properties are found in medium to very-coarse-grained sandstones 796
(25%; 341.89 mD). In well B, the best reservoir quality is found in less porous (16%) 797
but highly permeable distributary-channel conglomerates (313.24 mD). 798
6. Porosity and permeability were taken into account to define reservoir and non-799
reservoir zones. In well A, the sedimentary succession was divided into 11 reservoir 800
zones and 2 non-reservoirs. The best reservoir quality (very good) was found in thin 801
turbidites (reservoir zone 2) and superimposed channel-fill bars with low bioturbation 802
and mud contribution (reservoir zone 4). Good quality reservoir zone was found in 803
proximal delta front deposits (reservoir zone 8) in FST (F7–F9). Two thinner 804
reservoirs zones (9, 11), mostly composed of channel-fill bars deposited during OST 805
show good quality properties. Six low quality reservoir zones were described (1, 3, 5, 806
6, 7, 10). They are mostly formed by bioturbated and fluidized overbank deposits, 807
and subordinately proximal delta front sandbodies (3, 5) deposited in FST. In well B, 808
12 reservoir zones and one non-reservoir were identified. The best reservoir zones 809
(1, 9), with excellent to very good properties, were found in distributary channel 810
deposits. Reservoir zone 9 has very good quality. It is formed by trough cross-811
bedded conglomerates followed by channel bars, and capped by thick lacustrine 812
mudstones. Thick amalgamated conglomerates (reservoir zone 12) and thin, fine-813
grained reservoir zones (6, 8) in channel deposits show good reservoir properties. 814
Numerous low-quality reservoir zones (3, 4, 5) comprise ripple cross-laminated 815
sandstones deposited in distal bars. Poor fluid-flow properties (fair to good porosity) 816
33
resulted mostly from syn-sedimentary deformation of mud drapes, intense 817
bioturbation, and fluidization that caused heterogeneity, and highly decreased fluid-flow 818
properties. 819

Table 2. Summary of the lithofacies identified in the Barra de Itiúba Formation (wells A and B),
represented by dominant facies associations.
Facies Description Interpretation Gmm Massive, matrix-supported conglomerates, poorly
sorted; subangular grains; dominant quartz granules (subordinate feldspar and rock fragments); abundant mud clasts; 1.6 to 10 m thick beds.
Plastic debris flow (high-strength, viscous) (Miall, 1996).
Gt Clast-supported conglomerates with trough cross- stratification; subangular grains; dominant quartz and feldspar granules (rare rock fragments and mud clasts); 0.1 to 2 m thick sets.
3D gravel dunes (Rust, 1978; Todd, 1996).
Sh
Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with horizontal lamination; moderately- to well-sorted; 0.2 to 1 m thick beds.
Planar-bedded deposits originated via upper flow regime (Miall, 1977; Best and Bridge, 1992; Marshall, 2000).
Sl Fine- to coarse-grained sandstones with low-angle cross-stratification; moderately- to well-sorted; 0.2 to 0.9 m thick beds.
Washed-out dunes and humpack dunes (transition between subcritical and supercritical flows) (Harms et al., 1982).
St Fine- to coarse-grained sandstones with trough cross- stratification; poorly- to well-sorted; frequently fluidized and with weak bioturbation; sub-angular grains; Dominant quartz granules; locally erosive base; 0.15 to 2.8 m thick sets.
3D subaqueous sandy dunes deposited via lower flow regime (Harms et al.; 1982; Miall, 1996; Collinson et al.; 2006).
Sr Very fine- to medium-grained sandstones with ripple cross-lamination (subcritical to critical climbing angle); very frequently bioturbated; moderately- to well-sorted; centimeter-thick sets forming up to 2.4 m thick co-sets.
Small-scale ripple migration in unidirectional lower flow regime (Allen, 1963; Miall, 1996).
Sd
Fine- to medium-grained sandstones with convoluted lamination and flame structure; moderately- to well- sorted; sometimes bioturbated; 0.1 to 5.8 m thick beds.
Deposits deformed by fluidization.
Sb Very fine- to medium- grained sandstones with horizontal and vertical burrows; well sorted; 5.9 to 20 m thick beds.
Deposition deformed by bioturbation.
Sm Fine-to medium-grained, massive sandstones; locally subangular quartz granules; 0.2 to 2 m thick beds.
Deposition of hyperconcentrated flows, fluidization or intensive bioturbation (Todd, 1989; Miall, 1978, 1996).
H Heterolites with linsen bedding, formed by intercalation of massive siltstones and very fine-grained sandstones; frequently bioturbated; 0.1 to 1.6 m thick beds.
Variation of energy levels, with gravitational settling from suspension alternating with deposition from hyperconcentrated flows (Miall, 1996).
Hr Heterolites with linsen bedding and ripple cross- lamination (subcritical climbing angle); often bioturbation and fluidization; formed by intercalation of massive silt-mudstones and very fine- to fine-grained sandstones; 0.4 to 2.2 m thick beds.
Variation of energy levels, with gravitational settling from suspension alternating with deposition from ripple migration under unidirectional lower flow regime.
Fr
Siltstones- to very fine-grained sandstones with ripple cross-lamination (critical climbing angle); often bioturbated; moderately- to well-sorted; 0.15 to 1.5 m thick beds.
Low-energy tractive currents (Miall, 1977).
Fd Siltstones- to very fine-grained sandstones with convolute lamination; common load structures and bioturbation; 0.2 cm to 2.9 m thick beds.
Fine deposits deformed by fluidization.
Fl
Yellowish to gray mudstones to siltstones with horizontal lamination; moderately bioturbated; 0.15 to 2.7 m thick beds.
Suspension settling. Zero flow velocity (Astin & Rogers, 1991).
Fb Greenish to gray bioturbated mudstones, often convolute lamination; 0.1 cm to 3.5 m thick beds.
Suspension settling, deformed by bioturbation.
Fm
Greenish to gray, rarely yellowish, massive mudstones; 0.15 to 3.9 m thick beds.
Suspension settling. Zero flow velocity (Miall, 1977).
C Black, organic-rich mudstones; massive or laminated, may have coal fragments (<4 cm); slickensides, often ostracode-rich levels; 0.2 to 5 m thick beds.
Suspension settling of sediments under anoxic or poorly-oxidized conditions (Chakraborty and Sarkar, 2005; Foix et al., 2013).
P
Silty-mudstones with concretions, root traces, highly oxidized level; 40 cm thick bed.
Chemical precipitation in long time-prolonged sub-aerial exposure condition (Retallack, 2001). Intemperized soil.
